question.text: Which is the incorrect statement for <math><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal"> L</mi></math> sample of <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>)</mo></math> and <math><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>)</mo></math> at <math><mn>298</mn><mi mathvariant="normal"></mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> K</mi></math> and <math><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal"></mi><mi mathvariant="normal"></mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> pressure

options.text: The average translational <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>KE</mi></math> per molecule is the same in <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

The rms speed remains same for both <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> and  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

The density of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is less than that of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>
The most probable velocity is different for the two gases.

solution.text:
Kinetic energies per molecule will be same because it is proportional to absolute temperature only.
dN2dCO2=MN2MCO2=2844 i.e.,  d N 2 < d C O 2 .
Total translational kinetic energy will also be same because at same temperature & pressure number of molecules present in same volume would be same (according to Avogadro's Law)
Hint : rms speed has relation, USO2UO2=MO2TSO2MSO2TO2
